newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Belgium's Maystadt confirms debt reduction plan.
newsitem.headline: Belgium's Maystadt confirms debt reduction plan.

text.p: Belgian Finance Minister Philippe Maystadt confirmed on Monday the government was considering using part of the Belgian National Bank's (BNB's) foreign exchange reserves to cut the national debt.

In an interview with RTBF radio, Maystadt said the "possibility" of using the reserves for redeeming part of the debt was added to a draft law on the central bank's statutes which the government adopted last Friday.

Maystadt, who was asked to comment on an interview central bank governor Alfons Verplaetse gave to Reuters Financial Television last week, said the BNB had blocked in its books the equivalent of 230 billion Belgian francs of reserves generated from recent gold sales.
Under a plan envisaged by the government, this reserve "could be used directly to reduce the debt," Maystadt said.

"An operation of the kind envisaged by the governor of the national bank...would enable in the first year to reduce the interest charge on the debt by eight billion (francs), and by more in successive years," Maystadt said.
RTBF said the government aimed to slash the debt by 300 billion francs.

As well as the 230 billion francs from the National Bank, the government aimed to use proceeds from the 73 billion franc privatisation of state telephone company Belgacom late last year and the possible sale of more shares in state-controlled Bank ASLK-CGER either to Belgian-Dutch insurance group Fortis or via a bourse listing.
Senior government ministers were meeting again on Monday to hammer out the details of Belgium's 1997 budget, whose main aim is to qualify the country for European monetary union.
